children.subject:
I hope it's ok if I pin this post--I was trying to ask instructors about the policy of pinning posts but couldn't find the option. The course is not listed under EECS, but the content is very relevant, and the course staff is trying to recruit more students from the EECS department.

If it's not suitable to do so, please let me know, and I'll unpin immediately. Thanks, and apologies if this causes any trouble!
Like for other courses, you can take it as P/NP if it doesn't count towards your major requirements

Yeah, Helix's absolutely right about the PNP policy. The objective of the course is to bring awareness and understanding of the related issue. 



The programming assignments will be something similar to the labs in here: https://daylight.berkeley.edu/mlfailures/.
Are they in python?
Found the answer -> any language, but GSI's can offer support with python http://ziadobermeyer.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/AI-for-health-syllabus-public.pdf
Can this class be taken P/NP? Or does it have to be taken for a grade.

Probably not for now as it's a pretty new course. But I'll inform the course staffs and have them write a petition to the department. You can also bring the syllabus to the department office yourself to make the petition if the policy of students being able to write petition remains the same--but I haven't been checking it lately.
Perfect, thank you! Do you happen to know if the syllabus for Fall 2020 is the same as the Fall 2019 one? I believe the current syllabus is required to petition the technical elective policy.
You might want to directly email Samantha to get a current copy. It should be almost finalized (and won't be too much different from the previous one)!
You can submit a full syllabus to be evaluated here: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdcBZFU9YKC30KEarUg-JfEfmBk_qaBU-oNDpFDOHP4IWgMaQ/viewform.
Does this class count towards the "7 units of Upper Division Technical Electives" in the L&S CS major?
From Samamtha: we don’t know exactly when the small group discussions will be but they’ll be within the 3-6pm time so we can’t guarantee time conflicts will be allowed
Are time conflicts allowed for the course? If all of the lectures are pre-recorded I would assume so, but then you also mention small-group discussion over zoom. Thanks!
thats what it says on classes.berkeley.edu
Yes, it is. There's no alternative unit option.
Can this class only be taken for 3 units?
The programming tasks should be straightforward if u have done 61a or 61b. There will be 1-2 hours of reading assignments each week.
How many hours/week of work can we expect from this class?
Things may change depending on Prof. Obermeyer's schedule, but currently, yes.
is this course only available during the fall?

history.content:
PH 196: Artificial intelligence for medicine and health policy 

Fall 2020

Faculty Instructor: Ziad Obermeyer [zobermeyer@berkeley.edu]

 

GSI: Samantha Robertson [samantha_robertson@berkeley.edu]

 

Course Overview: Over the coming decades, data and algorithms will transform medicine and our health care system. Whether you plan to be a doctor, an algorithm developer, or work elsewhere in the health sector, this course will help you understand the tremendous upside of artificial intelligence for health: what the tools of machine learning can do in this important sector, and where they can do harm. The course will focus on teaching concepts, not the mechanics of specific algorithms. But genuine conceptual understanding requires engagement with technical content (e.g., readings from computer science and statistics, problem sets requiring analysis of real datasets with statistical software). As a result, it is designed for students who are already comfortable with basic data analysis, thanks to coursework in data science/computer science, biostatistics/statistics, or economics (e.g., you should already know how to load and manipulate datasets in statistical software).

 

Format: Mixture of pre-recorded video (3-4x 30min lectures) and live small-group discussion over Zoom. There will be online group exercises and projects, to build teamwork and community in this unusual semester, as well as problem sets and a midterm.

 

Fall 2019 Evaluations: (first year of class; 89% response rate)

  • Instructor: 6.26/7 (vs SPH mean: 5.97)

  • Overall effectiveness: 5.87/7 (5.92)

  • Engaging respectfully: 6.68/7 (6.37)

  • Climate: 6.55/7 (6.37)

Feel free to contact GSI: Samantha Robertson [samantha_robertson@berkeley.edu] if you have any further questions about the course!
